properties.media:imagetext:
Mr. Bixby
October 15, 1937
have Col. Lun's
word for it that Pan American will be made a payment
as soon as the plane reaches Hankow, and I hope your faith will be
justified.
I also hope that the
sale of the Connodores will go through
without any further hitch and will be satisfactorily handled at Hong
Kong in your
absence.
To close with a light touch,
if there can be such a
thing in such a serious situation, I was much intrigued at your state-
ment
that it is plamed to operate a service from Chungking to Hong
Kong with a DC-2 vie Knelyang
and #a point in Kwangsi Province", You
can imagine what Mr. Priester's feelings would be towards
such a care-
fully prepared
operation as this!
Fortunately he does not consider
these operations now to be under his supervision, as I would certainly
never
date to ley this suggestion before him.
I find on the map there
are a lot of
towns in Kwangei,
and. I assume
any. of them will do for the
purpose you weil have in mind!
I an a bit at a loss to know how you
are going to get gasoline and other supplies in there, as well as to
Kweiyang,
and the thought of inaugurating this operation over this un-
surveyed
route with Messrs.
Sweet, Smith, and another whose nane you
do not
even
know;
together with the prospect of coming into Canton
(which I understand is periodically
under attack by the Japanese air
force)
fills me with apprehension.
Furthermore, as this is a round-
about route with Eurasia holding the advantage of the shorter line Canton-
Hankow, I wonder if you really think the operation would be worth the
risks and difficulties involved. I doubt if we would get much, if any,
international airmail over that route, in which case it would only be
of doubtful political value so far as
the Washington picture is con-
cerned.
Referring above to the Japanese brings up another
thought
which Ian sure you have not lost sight of, which is the very doubtful
value of any assurances or guarantees you may obtain from the Japanese
military.
The papers only yesterday reported the machine-gunning of
three officiel automobiles which had the British flag painted on their
roofs.
It is true
that they were travelling fairly near the scene of
active operations, but of course the Japanese aircraft must cruise
fairly widely.
I am wondering, just how much faith you can put in the
green color with which you plan to baptize the CNAC planes.
call that in one of your earlier letters you put the danger to our
planes as being from the Chinese and Japanese militaries in that order:
In concluding this rather gloomy letter,
which I hope
w111 not arrive until
everything has been worked out right, let me say
in all
sincerity that I admire very
much your even trying to go ahead
on these plans, and the desperate efforts you are making to work out
something to protect the conpany's interests.
I only hope that you will
not let your anxiety to achieve the impossible lead you too far.
